_header: I had my silver and my friend
Note:
For a later version expanded into long lines cf. Oxford, Bodleian Library Rawlinson poet. 172 , f.12v; Oxford, Bodleian Library Gough Norfolk 43, f.31v; Arundel Castle, Duke of Norfolk MS Arundel-Harrington, f.16, pr. Hughey (1935)
XHughey, Ruth. The Harington Manuscript at Arundel Castle and related documents. n.p., 1935, 1.79. For a longer and later text cf. Rimbault (1851)
XRimbault, Edward Francis. A Little Book of Songs and Ballads. London: J. R. Smith, 1851, 42; Hawkins (1776)
XHawkins, Sir Thomas. A General History of the Science and Practice of Music. 5 vols. London: T. Payne, 1776, 3.38; Hughey (1935)
XHughey, Ruth. The Harington Manuscript at Arundel Castle and related documents. n.p., 1935, 2.3-4; cf. also 2333 and 6330.
_description: A warning against lending money — four monorhyming lines

BodLauMis23.Transcription:
I had my syluer And my frendI lent my syluer To my frendI askyd
                    my syluer Of my frendI lost my syluer And my frend
BodLauMis23.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             A Register of Middle English Religious & Didactic Verse.
         2 vols. London: Oxford University Press for the Bibliographical
            Society: 1916-20: 1.1.

BodRawD328.Transcription:
When y lent y ad a fryndeand when y aschede he was own
                    kendeþus off my frynde y made my fowand therfor y woll lene no
                    more

OxfMagdEstate.Transcription:
I had my catel and my frendI lente my catel to my frendI asked
                    my catel of my frendI loste my catel and my friend
OxfMagdEstate.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: no. 87.
O’Donoghue,  Berna,  and  Christopher Woolgar.  
             “Three Early Fifteenth-Century Poems at Magdalen College,
                Oxford.” 
             Notes and Queries
         n.s. 27 [225] (1980): 497-500: 498.

CULEe435a.Transcription:
I had mey God & mey ffrende[I] lant mey Good to mey
                    [ffrende]I Axyd mey God off mey ffrende[I] lost me Good & mey
                    [ffrende]

BLAdd24542.Transcription:
I once had money and a friend and did them both foreserueI lend my
                    money to my friend his needful ease to serueI askt my money of my friend no
                    though the case was strangeI lost my money and my friend and found a foe in
                    change

BLAdd37049.Editions:
Doty,  Brant Lee,
                        ed.  
             “An Edition of British Museum MS Additional 37049: a Religious
                Miscellany.” 
         Diss. Michigan State, 1969: 482.

BLCottTitAXXVI.Transcription:
Whan I lente I fynde a frende& when I aske I am vnkyndethus
                    of my ffrende I make my foother for wyll I lene nomor

BLHar116.Transcription:
I had my good And my frendI lent my good To my frendI askyd my
                    good Of my frendI lost my good And my frendI made of my frend my
                    fooI will be war I do no more soo
BLHar116.Note:
4 lines, monorhyming, set out with first few words of each line in one
                    column with a common ‘good’ to right, then next few words in a
                    second column with a common ‘ffrend’ to right. Followed by lines 5-6
                    of 2333; added to flyleaf by a
                    hand of the fifteenth to sixteenth century.

BLHar4800.Editions:
Cumming,  William Patterson,
                        ed.  
             The Revelations of St. Birgitta, from Garrett MS. Princeton
                University.
EETS
         o.s. 178 (1929); repr. 1987: xviii.

DULCosViii5.Transcription:
I had my mony ande my frendas many a man hathe in londeI lent my
                    mony to my frendas dothe bothe fre and bonde
DULCosViii5.Note:
Variant; two more copies, f. 163ra; all added to original
                    blank flyleaf at end.

GULHun409.Transcription:
I had my frynde and my sylverI lent my frynde To my sylverI
                    Asked my frynde Of my sylverI loste my frynde And my sylver
GULHun409.Note:
Six lines, written as a missing-word puzzle, with ‘frynde’
                    and ‘sylver’ filled in once each to serve all four lines, in reverse
                    positions; added by a later hand to lower margin.
